response.message: That's actually pretty impressive work. Who knew an about page could be so interesting? This is a great model for others to learn from!

I'll just leave this link right here...

http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/101935/can-the-ask-question-page-be-changed-to-obtain-better-quality-questions

If you want people to get a clue what the boxes are supposed to do, be more expressive about it

 Just being slightly more verbose makes you get rid of those silly three word titles that don't add anything useful, posts lacking details and examples or people wondering what a "tag" is.

Have you ever tried to fill in a survey where each box is accompanied with _at most_ a single word? That's not constructive.
I like the new About page it's clean and simple to understand good work!
"The best answers show up first so that they are always easy to find" contradicts with "Accepting doesn't mean it's the best answer" since generally accepted answers always show up before any others.

This is good work. I'm sure that SE is trying to limit the amount of crud in the top navigation bar, but maybe "About" should be put back there, so users don't have to scroll all the way to the bottom to find out that an "About" page even exists. Have put a link on top of the Writers FAQ, but the editing options there make this a clunky solution. Maybe there's an official way to make this a visually smoother solution?

> Now, obviously, users could just discover these things as they use the site, but however much you do or don’t grok our system, surprises suck.

This... is not really true:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8FpigqfcvlM

That said, the new about page is awesome and very well implemented. Definitely a big step in the right direction.

(And to @neil above, the about link is only suppressed for experienced users, who presumably know all that stuff by now. Try viewing the site as a new user or in your browser's inprivate, incognito, etc browsing mode.
Definitely very well done, but of what use is it if even an eager new user does not find a link to it anywhere but in the footer on beta sites?

> Tagging may not seem like something a new user needs to be thinking about, but it’s actually critical because almost invariably, they get it wrong.

Surely it would be possible to parse new question title and description content and pull tags from existing words (in fact, given that new tags cannot be created spuriously, this makes more sense than forcing the user to enter his or her own tags).

For cases where there is not one tag automatically retrieved for a question, (seems unlikely, but possible) what about an (untagged) tag and an "untagged" /review queue?

I believe one of the early studies on tags discovered that people who were posting something were far poorer at tagging than a collection of people who were reading something. Perhaps for newbies with less than, say, 1000 reputation, it might be a better user experience to have the community tag their questions?

@Jason: realistically, if the author can get one or two critical tags right ([c#] [jquery]), the folks reading, reviewing and answering can fix the rest (+[dom] +[asp.net-mvc] -[porgramming] -[halp]).
About Page 2.0 is very impressive, hope SE will continue it's journey of innovations :).

I somehow feel this entire post is one big déjà vu.

Anyway, you guys did a great job with the new About page. Can't wait to see what changes you'll do with the whole questions closing system :) .
Impressive!!!!

Excellent page! One comment though: please change "The best answers show up first so that they are always easy to find" to "The answers with the most votes show up first so that they are always easy to find"

The new About page is a classic example of group think gone wrong.  The text makes no sense at all to a new user.  It's merely a statement of how the site's administrators define themselves.

For example:

"It's built and run by you"

Now I know what this means, but someone with a programming question doesn't.  He also doesn't want to clear his mind of useful problem-related information and sit down for a help page.

Nobody reads help pages anyway.

Worst idea ever.
@Andomar Really? This is the worse idea ever? Hyperbolic much?
@Dave: I guess invading Russia in the winter would be a slightly worse idea ;-)

This is great information & pretty entertaining too.
I think that from now on, I'll link new users to about page rather than the homepage :)
@Andomar: Thanks for your reply.  You've now been nominated as the Project Manager for About Page Version 3.0.

Not sure if it's a real problem but to get the informed badge you only have to go to the bottom of the page: eg by pressing the End key.  So you can get the badge without, even theoretically, reading the entire page.

Nice work, I like it.
I'm not sure on putting/hiding it inside the about page; "about" pages generally contain boring information and people do not read them (imho).

Any chance of being able to make minor edits to the good/bad topics like we can with the FAQ? I notice that our main bullet points were used, and I'm all for conciseness, but we have 5 "dos" and only 4 "don'ts" and there's one "don't" I really think should have been included.

What do we do/who do we ask?
